name: OK UK Online Trivia | Mixed UK | 25 Questions

questions.text: Jimmy Gulzar was married to which famous British celebrity?
questions.explanation: Mel B.

questions.text: Who was the long-time host of the Channel 4 programme 'Countdown'?
questions.explanation:
Richard Whiteley.

	'Countdown' was presented by Richard Whiteley from its first show until his death. The programme celebrated its 20th year in 2002.

questions.text: Who founded the Metropolitan Police Force in 1829?
questions.explanation:
Robert Peel.

	Peel was born in 1788 and died in a riding accident in 1850.

questions.text: What is the surname of the former British sportsman who has starred in the films 'Snatch', 'Gone in 60 Seconds' and 'Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels'?
questions.explanation:
Jones & Vinnie Jones & Vinny Jones.

	Vinnie Jones played football for Wimbledon, Chelsea, Leeds and Sheffield United and represented Wales at the international level, before going into acting.

questions.text: The chat show 'Trisha' used to be filmed in which city?
questions.explanation:
Norwich.

	'Trisha' was filmed at the Anglia studios in Norwich.

questions.text: What were banned from the outside lane of motorways in 1996?
questions.explanation:
Buses.

	In 1999 a stretch of the M4 near Heathrow had this lane reserved for buses, taxis, coaches and minibuses, and this has proved to be helpful for the movement of traffic in busy periods.

questions.text: Which singer injured his foot when he kicked a microphone across the stage on a Norwegian TV show?
questions.explanation:
Jarvis Cocker.

	Jarvis Cocker is the lead singer of Pulp.

questions.text: Which year did the Queen describe as an 'annus horribilis'?
questions.explanation:
1992.

	Divorces in the family, followed by the fire at Windsor Castle.  Little wonder it was a horrible year for Her Majesty.

questions.text: What was the name of the dog in Enid Blyton's 'The Famous Five' books?
questions.explanation:
Timmy & Tim & timothy.

	There were two boys, Julian and Dick, and two girls, Anne and George (Georgina).  Timmy the dog made the fifth member of the gang.

questions.text: Whose real name is Anthony Robert McMillan?
questions.explanation: Robbie Coltrane.

questions.text: What do the initials DVLA stand for?
questions.explanation:
Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency.

	The DVLA is located in Swansea in Wales.  Their database has the ownership details of every vehicle in the country.  Crooks permitting, of course.

questions.text: Who played Barry Grant in the soap opera 'Brookside'?
questions.explanation:
Paul Usher.

	Paul Usher went on to the TV cop series 'The Bill'. Steven played Max Farnham and Vince played Ron Dixon. Ricky Tomlinson used to play Barry Grant's dad, Bobby Grant. He is better known for his part in BBC1's 'The Royle Family'.

questions.text: Which Scottish river is famed for its salmon fishing, and contains the Orton Water?
questions.explanation:
Spey.

	The Orton Water is situated eight miles upstream from the mouth of the river Spey, and is a  one and a half mile stretch providing fishing from both banks.

questions.text: In which year was the kids TV series 'Grange Hill' first shown?
questions.explanation:
1978.

	Grange Hill was a school set in the East End of London.  Its first class, new to the senior school from the juniors, included Todd Carty and Susan Tully, both of whom became familiar faces to all through 'EastEnders'.

questions.text: On an English Monopoly board, what colour is Vine Street?
questions.explanation:
Orange.

	Marlborough Street and Bow Street are also orange.

questions.text: Name one of the two stadiums which share the same name, where Premiership Football and Test and County Cricket have played?
questions.explanation:
Old Trafford & the riverside & riverside.

	Old Trafford is the name of the home of Manchester United. It is also the name of the Test match cricket ground and the home of Lancashire cricket club.  Middlesbrough FC plays at Riverside stadium, and the Durham County Cricket ground at Chester-le-Street is The Riverside. (Thanks to player mfc for this additional information.)

questions.text: In which languages are some street signs written in Chester?
questions.explanation: English - Welsh - Latin.

questions.text: Which British group has a one-armed drummer?
questions.explanation:
Def Leppard.

	The drummer was called Rick Allen.

questions.text: Royal wedding rings for the UK's royal family are traditionally made with gold from which country?
questions.explanation: Wales.

questions.text: Which, out of the four options, gained city status in 2000 and is home to Eden Court Theatre?
questions.explanation: Inverness.

questions.text: Wheel clamps were first used on illegally parked cars in the UK in which decade?
questions.explanation:
1980s.

	1983 was the first year in which they were used.

questions.text: What colour balls were used at Wimbledon before yellow ones replaced them?
questions.explanation: White.

questions.text: Which bird is traditionally associated with the Tower of London?
questions.explanation:
Raven.

	Tradition says that when the Ravens leave, the Tower will fall.  The Ravens are treated as pets by the Beefeaters, and carefully looked after to ensure the Tower remains standing.

questions.text: Wales has only one passport office. Where is it?
questions.explanation:
Newport.

	The UK has six passport offices. The others are in London, Liverpool, Peterborough, Glasgow and Belfast.

questions.text: Which long established UK daily newspaper has a three-letter name (not including 'the')?
questions.explanation: Sun & The Sun.
